attributes.action: Fund defibrillators and emergency first aid training for all schools
attributes.additional_details: There are too many cases where a lack of first aid skills or access to emergency equipment such as defibrillators can put the lives of children at risk. Providing funding for defibrillators and emergency first aid training for all schools should help save lives.
attributes.background: I believe that every school in this country should have at least 1 defibrillator and a number of staff who are sufficiently trained to use it as well as CPR. The Government should provide funding for this to ensure our children are better protected in the future.

other_parliamentary_business.body:
On Tuesday 4 July, Abena Oppong-Asare MP led a Westminster Hall debate in Parliament on public access to defibrillators.
Watch the debate (https://parliamentlive.tv/event/index/2d0fa631-ee13-4a07-8a29-c5ff4ed2febb?in=14:30:26)
Read a transcript of the debate (https://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/2023-07-04/debates/09D1D27E-F510-467E-9041-F5FC7A6B657D/DefibrillatorsPublicAccess)
During the debate MPs discussed access to and awareness of publicly available defibrillators. They also discussed the VAT arrangements for defibrillators. 
What are Westminster Hall debates?
Westminster Hall is the second Chamber of the House of Commons. 
Westminster Hall debates give MPs an opportunity to raise local or national issues and receive a response from a government minister. Any MP can take part in a Westminster Hall debate. 
Debates in Westminster Hall take place on ‘general debate' motions expressed in neutral terms. These motions are worded ‘That this House has considered [a specific matter]'. 
Get involved in the work of the UK Parliament
Sign up to the Your UK Parliament newsletter (https://parliament.us16.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=3ad7e4c57a864f07e4db008c4&id=26d0645ea9) for the latest information on how to get involved and make a difference.
other_parliamentary_business.subject: MPs debate public access to defibrillators

other_parliamentary_business.body:
MPs held a debate on public access to defibrillators on Wednesday 20 March in Westminster Hall. The debate was led by Jonathan Gullis MP. The Minister for Health and Secondary Care, Andrew Stephenson MP responded on behalf of the Government.
Watch the debate (https://parliamentlive.tv/event/index/13ea61b4-1802-4fb1-81ef-845c0838372f?in=16:00:10)
Read a transcript of the debate (https://hansard.parliament.uk/Commons/2024-03-20/debates/C244D828-B73E-4540-9ECC-752CB75F5181/Defibrillators)
MPs discussed access to defibrillators in schools, vehicles and public places, as well as increasing training for the public.
What is a Westminster Hall debate?
Westminster Hall is the second chamber of the House of Commons. Westminster Hall debates give MPs an opportunity to raise local and national issues and receive a response from a government minister. Westminster Hall debates are general debates that do not end in a vote. 
Visual explainer: Westminster Hall debates (https://ukparliament.shorthandstories.com/cet-westminster-hall-debates/index.html?utm_campaign=&utm_medium=email&utm_source=petcom&utm_term=petitioners)
Get involved in the work of the UK Parliament
Sign up to the Your UK Parliament newsletter (https://parliament.us14.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=098af33234df9814f59fb205f&id=6e29cb1262) for the latest information on how to get involved and make a difference.
